Erlaubte Hilfsmittel: Selbstverfasste, handgeschriebene Notizen auf 6 A4-Seiten. Es ist erlaubt ein Wörterbuch zu benutzen. Es sind keine weiteren Hilfsmittel erlaubt. 2.) Falls nicht explizit ausgeschlossen dürfen Resultate (z.B. Lemmas oder Theoreme) aus dem Skript mit entsprechendem Verweis (z.B. “Lemma Skript”; die Nummer ist nicht notwending falls klar ist welches Resultat gemeint ist) ohne Beweis verwendet werden. Resultate aus der Übung dürfen nicht ohne Beweis verwendet werden. 3.) Die Aufgaben sind in drei Schwierigkeitsstufen von (⋆) bis (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) eingeteilt. 4.) Die Aufgaben sind direkt auf dem Prüfungsblatt zu lösen. Bei Platzmangel beﬁnden sich am Ende der Prüfung vier Zusatzblätter. Weitere Zusatzblätter können während der Prüfung bei uns bezogen werden. Nur von uns verteilte Zusatzblätter sind erlaubt. 5.) Die Antwortfelder unter den Aufgaben sind jeweils grosszügig bemessen. Es ist oft nicht die Erwartung, dass eine Antwort das ganze Feld füllt. 6.) Bitte verwenden Sie einen dokumentenechten Stift (also keinen Bleistift) und nicht die Farben Rot oder Grün. 7.) Bitte legen Sie die Legi für die Ausweiskontrolle auf den Tisch. 8.) Sie dürfen bis 10 Minuten vor Ende der Prüfung vorzeitig abgeben und den Raum still verlassen. 9.) Mobiltelefone und Smartwatches müssen komplett ausgeschaltet sein (kein Standby) und dürfen nicht am Körper getragen werden. Prüfungs-Nr. The sets ∅ × ∅ and {∅} × {∅} are equal. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 2.) The set {∅, {∅}} is a subset of {∅}. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 3.) For any two ﬁnite sets A and B we have |A ∪ B| = |A| + |B|. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 4.) For any two sets A and B there exists a set C such that A = B ∩ C or B = A ∩ C. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 5.) For any set A, we have A ∩ P(A) = ∅. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 6.) The relation ρ = {(1, 2), (2, 1)} is transitive. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 7.) The composition of two reﬂexive relations on some set A is always reﬂexive. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 8.) 72 is the least upper bound of {4, 6, 9} in the poset ({4, 6, 9, 18, 24, 48, 54, 72, 288}; |). (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 9.) The set { f ∈ {0, 1}N | ∀n ∈ N f (2n) = f (4n)} is countable. (2 Points) 2 True 2 False 10.) If the transitive closure of a binary relation ρ is uncountable, then ρ must be uncountable. (2 Points) 2 True 2 False b) (⋆) Let ρ and σ be relations on some non-empty set A. Prove or disprove: If ρ is antisymmetric and σ is antisymmetric, then ρ ◦ σ is antisymmetric. (4 Points) Page 2 of 21 c) (⋆) Let A and B be two sets. (i) Describe the set (A \ B) ∪ (B \ A) with the two sets A ∩ B and A ∪ B in an expression which contains only A ∩ B, A ∪ B, parentheses, as well as the symbols ∪, ∩, \, and ×. Each of A ∩ B and A ∪ B is allowed to appear at most twice. No justiﬁcation is required. (1 Point) (ii) We ﬁx an arbitrary element x. Phrase the statement that x is in the set (A \ B) ∪ (B \ A) if and only if it is in the set described in your answer of (i) as an equivalence of two propositional formulas F and G. Use only two atomic formulas U and V , where U being true is interpreted as x ∈ A and V being true is interpreted as x ∈ B. No justiﬁcation is required. (2 Points) (iii) Prove that the two formulas described in (ii) are equivalent. (2 Points) Page 3 of 21 d) (⋆) Let ρ be a reﬂexive relation on a non-empty A set such that a ρ b ∧ b ρ c =⇒ c ρ a for any a, b, c ∈ A. Prove that ρ is an equivalence relation. (4 Points) Page 4 of 21 e) (⋆ ⋆) Let Y be a non-empty ﬁnite set and let f : N → Y be an arbitrary function. Prove the following statement: There exists a strictly increasing function g : N → N such that f ◦ g is constant. (6 Points) Hint: A function h : A → B is constant if h(a1) = h(a2) for all a1, a2 ∈ A. Hint: A function h : N → N is strictly increasing if x < y =⇒ h(x) < h(y) for any x, y ∈ N. Page 5 of 21 Task 2. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 2.) For any a, b ∈ N \ {0} and any x, y ∈ Z: x ≡ab y if and only if x ≡a y and x ≡b y. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 3.) For any a, b ∈ Z: If there exist u, v, d ∈ Z such that ua + vb = d, then gcd(a, b) = d. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False b) (⋆) Prove that for any a, b ∈ Z such that a2 = b3 + 2, we have a2 = 4q + 1 for some q ∈ Z. (4 Points) Page 6 of 21 c) (⋆ ⋆) Let S ⊆ Z be an inﬁnite set such that (i) a − b ∈ S for any a ∈ S and b ∈ S, and (ii) (c) ⊆ S for any c ∈ S. Prove that there exists u ∈ S such that (u) = S. (6 Points) Hint: Recall that for any d ∈ Z, we have (d) = { l · d | l ∈ Z }. Page 7 of 21 d) (⋆ ⋆ ⋆) Prove that for any a, b, c, d ∈ N \ {0} we have ab = cd =⇒ a + b + c + d is not prime. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 4.) In the ring Z2[x], the polynomials x2 + 1 and x + 1 are equal. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 5.) Let G = ⟨g⟩ be an inﬁnite cyclic group. For any i, j ∈ Z with i ̸= j we have gi ̸= gj. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False b) (⋆) Compute the inverse of x in the group Z5[x]∗ x2+1. (1 Point) c) (⋆) Let G; ·, −1 , e  be a commutative group and ﬁx an arbitrary element z ∈ G. Consider the algebra ⟨G; ⋆⟩ with a ⋆ b def = z · (a · b) for any a, b ∈ G. Prove that there exists e′ ∈ G such that ⟨G; ⋆, e′⟩ is a monoid. (4 Points) Page 9 of 21 d) (⋆) Disprove the following claim: For any two groups G and H, all subgroups of the direct product group G × H are of the form G′ × H ′, where G′ is a subgroup of G and H ′ a subgroup of H. (3 Points) Page 10 of 21 e) (i) (⋆ ⋆) Let ⟨G; ⋆, ̂, eG⟩ and H; ⊙, −1, eH  be two ﬁnite groups, and let ψ : G → H be an injective group homomorphism. Prove that for any x ∈ G we have ord(x) = ord(ψ(x)). (4 Points) Hint: You can use the fact that for any x ∈ G and any i ∈ Z we have ψ(xi) = ψ(x)i. (ii) (⋆ ⋆) Prove or disprove: There exists an injective homomorphism from Z∗ 14 to Z14. (4 Points) Hint: You can use the result from (i) even if you did not prove it. For any formula F , the formulas ∀xF and ∀yF are equivalent. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 3.) For any formula F , the formula ∃xF is satisﬁable if and only if F is satisﬁable. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 4.) The statement F ∧ G is satisﬁable if and only if F is satisﬁable and G is satisﬁable is true for any formulas F and G. (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 5.) The following derivation rule ∅ ⊢ F → (¬F → ¬G) for a propositional calculus is correct (sound). (1 Point) 2 True 2 False 6.) The following derivation rule F ⊢ ¬G → ¬(F → G) for a propositional calculus is correct (sound). (1 Point) 2 True 2 False b) (⋆) Consider the universe U = Z. Express each of the following statements with a formula, in which the only predicates appearing are less, equals and prime (instead of less(n, m) and equals(n, m) you can write n < m and n = m accordingly). You can also use the symbols + and · to denote addition and multiplication, and you can use constants (e.g., 0, 1, . . .). No justiﬁcation is required. (4 Points) i) The sum of two primes is never a prime. ii) Every integer that is divisible by 3 and greater than 2 is the product of two primes. We combine Π1 and Π2 into a third proof system Π3 = (S1 × S2, P1 × P2, τ3, ϕ3), where τ3(s1, s2) = 1 def ⇐⇒ τ1(s1) = 1 or τ2(s2) = 1, and ϕ3((s1, s2), (p1, p2)) = 1 def ⇐⇒ ϕ1(s1, p1) = 1 or ϕ2(s2, p2) = 1. Prove or disprove: If Π3 is complete, then Π1 or Π2 is complete.
